subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] My Progress
msgSnippet: Very nice! On 23 April 2018 at 03:08, Nathan Galt mailinglists@ngalt.com ... Very nice!   On 23 April 2018 at 03:08, Nathan Galt mailinglists@ngalt.com
messageBody:
Very nice!  

On 23 April 2018 at 03:08, Nathan Galt mailinglists@... [Read_Alphabet] <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
 

Looks great! No, seriously — your handwriting is way better than mine. I couldn’t produce text that nice even if I tried my best.

> Also, since my dialect of English does not use the sound of Letter 20, but instead uses Letter 18, I use only Letter 18 for all words with "w" sounds, and eschew the use of Letter 20.

Yeah, “wine” and “whine” are homophones for me, too. Of all the distinctions that midcentury Brits make that I don’t, the w/ʍ one is probably the easiest to replicate: use ·way for anything written with a “w” and ·why for anything written with a “wh”.

I’d love to see more of this. Keep the posts coming!

> On Apr 22, 2018, at 4:26 PM, gpdiqhfx45cwvckybgkazrwe22guir 3me33fnyth@... [Read_Alphabet] <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com > wrote:
>
> [Attachment(s) from gpdiqhfx45cwvckybgkazrwe22guir 3me33fnyth@... [Read_Alphabet] included below]
> I'm new to Yahoo Groups, so please forgive me if I don't do this right.
>
> As someone else said, once you memorize the Junior letters, the next logical step is to study pages 12-22 in The Manual, and immerse yourself in Senior Quikscript. It looks intimidating at first, but it's not that hard, really.
>
> I've written out in (what I believe is) fairly legible Senior sonnet number 57 by Shakespeare, the same one partially quoted by Captain James T. Kirk in the STOS episode Plato's Stepchildren. I will attach it in an image file.
>
> I made full use of the Senior Quikscript contractions on page 17 of the Manual, so you may need to refer to it.
> Also, since my dialect of English does not use the sound of Letter 20, but instead uses Letter 18, I use only Letter 18 for all words with "w" sounds, and eschew the use of Letter 20.
>
> I include the Roman text of the sonnet below for reference:
>
> Being your slave, what should I do but tend
> Upon the hours and times of your desire?
> I have no precious time at all to spend,
> Nor services to do till you require.
> Nor date I chide the world-without-end hour
> Whilst I, my sovereign, watch the clock for you,
> Nor think the bitterness of absence sour
> When you have bid your servant once adieu.
> Nor dare I question with my jealous thought
> Where you may be, or your affairs suppose
> But, like a sad slave, stay and think of nought
> Save where you are how happy you make those.
> So true a fool is love that in your Will,
> Though you do anything, he thinks no ill.
>
>
